section: 1.1 Provision of Services. (a) Provider agrees to provide the Services set forth on the Exhibit A attached hereto (as such Exhibit may be amended or supplemented pursuant to the terms of this Agreement, the "Exhibit") to Recipient for the respective periods and on the other terms and conditions set forth in this Agreement and in the Exhibit. However, Provider is not obligated to respond to any request by Recipient for access to any additional services and resources that are necessary for the operation of the Recipient and which are not currently contemplated in the Exhibit, unless Provider deems it fit and feasible.
explanation: This section creates an ambiguity regarding the Provider's obligations. While the Provider agrees to provide services listed in Exhibit A, it reserves the right to refuse additional services even if they are necessary for the Recipient's operation. This creates a contradiction as to what the Recipient can expect from the Provider during the agreement.

section: 3.1 Termination of Agreement. This Agreement be deemed effective as of the Effective Date, Agreement and shall terminate on December 31, 2020, unless terminated earlier in accordance with Section 3.2.
explanation: The language in this section is structurally flawed and does not make sense. It repeats the word "Agreement" and doesn't present a clear statement regarding the agreement's effective date.

section: 1.4 Intellectual Property. (a) Recipient shall own, all rights, title, and interest in any invention, technique, process, device, discovery, improvement, or know-how, whether patentable or not and all other proprietary rights, industrial rights and any other similar rights, in each case on a worldwide basis, and all copies and tangible embodiments thereof, or any part thereof, in whatever form or medium hereafter made or conceived solely by Provider, if both parties agree it is related to the services.
explanation: This section says if both parties agree it is related to the services, but it doesn't define what 'related to the services' mean. It may cause the parties to have a dispute. This statement creates a contradiction as to what the Recipient can expect to own as intellectual property.
